title: Trump‚Äôs rhetoric may have escalated insecurity in Nigeria, Omojuwa tells US senator
description: Japheth Omojuwa, an author and political commentator, saysUS President Donald Trump‚Äôs remarks on Nigeria may have led to an upsurge ininsecurity in the country. He added that he did not share the notion that NigerianChristians feel reassured by Trump‚Äôs offer of protection from ‚Äúpersecution‚Äù. Omojuwa offered his perspective while posing a question toKevin Cramer, US senator, at the three-day Halifax International Security Forumin Canada. Omojuwa is a member of the Halifax Forum board. Before the influencer‚Äôs comments, Cramer said Christians inNigeria today are probably feeling ‚Äúpretty good‚Äù about Trump‚Äôs position. Trump had threatened to send US troops ‚Äúguns-a-blazing‚Äù intoNigeria, a country he called ‚Äúdisgraced‚Äù, to wipe out the ‚ÄúIslamist terrorists‚Äùhe said were killing Christians. In a clip of his response to Cramer shared on X on Monday,Omojuwa said he offered a different view because he speaks as a Christianliving in Nigeria. ‚ÄúI do not feel good about Donald Trump. He called Nigeria adisgraced country. Frankly speaking, that‚Äôs not so bad, because he used to callus a shit hole country. So it‚Äôs a kind of improvement,‚Äù Omojuwa said. He followed by asking if powerful nations could offerassistance more respectfully, and without doing so in a way that leaves othersworse off. ‚ÄúFor instance, America went to Libya. Libya has a causativeeffect on the terrorism challenges Nigeria and the Sahel are facing. I don‚Äôtwant to talk about the other places America went to. Let‚Äôs just take it toNigeria,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúSince Donald Trump said what he said for NigerianChristians, Christians have been abducted in the church in the north-west ofNigeria. ‚ÄúMuslim students have been abducted. I do not speak to thecausation but there‚Äôs a correlation from the point Donald Trump spoke aboutNigeria‚Äôs challenges and the escalation of terrorism. ‚ÄúSo decency apart, there are rules of engagement, there‚Äôs arules based global order. Is there a way to speak about Nigeria, first of all,in a respectful, decent way, not even just as president of America, but as ahuman being?‚Äù Omojuwa also pointed to the failed arms deal between the USand Nigeria as playing a role in the weakened fight against terrorism. ‚ÄúIs there a way to decently help Nigeria without makingthings worse and without disrespecting Nigerian Christians and Muslims?‚Äù heasked. The US senator replied in the affirmative. ‚ÄúThe right words help. A more delicate way of sayingsomething is obviously better than a more brutal way,‚Äù Cramer said. ‚ÄúA lot of people will say the right thing and do the wrongthing. Other people will maybe say the wrong thing and mean to do the rightthing. Is there a better way to say? Certainly.‚Äù However, the senator said he believed that foreign aidassistance would be more effective in stemming terrorism, noting that he hadpublicly disagreed with Trump multiple times on the aid cuts. ‚ÄúI think, globally speaking, aid to friends, and would-befriends, and possible friends is a bargain compared to munitions,‚Äù he said. Cramer also posited that assistance would need to suit localcontexts.

title: US judge tosses cases against ex-FBI chief Comey, New York AG James
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -A federal judge on Monday dismissed criminal charges against two perceived adversaries of President Donald Trump, FBI Director James Comey and New York Attorney General Letitia James, ruling the U.S. attorney he hand picked to prosecute them was unlawfully appointed.
